title: Indigenous and international non biomedical treatments for diabetes in Brazil: an exploratory study of use in social context.
abstractText:
Existing social research on complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) has largely focused on its place within prosperous late/postmodern societies; existing work on traditional medicine (TM) on its role in poorer countries. This concentration on global extremes has produced work unable to make sense of processes within many countries that fall between these extremes, countries where both CAM and TM are an established feature of healthcare. We will conduct the first such study in Brazil (an excellent example of such a country) focusing on people with diabetes. This research will:

  1. add an extra level of sophistication to our understanding of themes within existing CAM sociology; and,
  2. address concerns of local users, by providing evidence that can contribute to more informed decision making on CAM/TM in Brazil.
